About This Game

The year is 1962 and the Cold War has the nation gripped by fear. Â A top-secret government unit called The Bureau begins investigating a series of mysterious attacks by an enemy more powerful than communism. Â As agent Carter, call the shots, pull the trigger and lead your squad in a gripping third-person tactical shooter set within a covert war to protect humanity from an otherworldly enemy.Â

Windows
Mac OS X
    Minimum:
    • OS: Windows Vista Service Pack 2 32-bit
    • Processor: Intel Core 2 DUO 2.4 GHz / AMD Athlon X2 2.7 GHz
    • Memory: 2 GB RAM
    • Graphics: DirectX9 Compatible ATI Radeon HD 3870 / NVIDIA 8800 GT
    • Hard Drive: 12 GB available space
    • Sound Card: DirectX Compatible
    • Additional Notes: Incompatible with Intel HD 3000 Integrated Graphics

    • Memory: 4 GB RAM
    • Graphics: DirectX11 Compatible, AMD Radeon HD 6950 / NVIDIA GeForce GTX 560
    • Hard Drive: 12 GB available space
    • Sound Card: DirectX Compatible
    • Additional Notes: Incompatible with Intel HD 3000 Integrated Graphics

    • OS: Mac OS X Mountain Lion 10.7.5 or higher
    • Processor: Intel Core i series processor

    • Hard Drive: 15 GB available space
    • Additional Notes: Keyboard and 3 button Mouse or Logitech Dual Analog Stick Gamepad

Murphy's Lawyer
727 products in account
96 reviews
Recommended
18.0 hrs on record
Posted: August 5
The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is an action-tactical, third-person shooter that incorporates cover systems, tactical pausing, and squad commands to make for riveting combat scenarios. The story is fairly enthralling and while the characters are definitely clichÃ©, I thought they were diverse and interesting enough, with the exception being the unquestionably boring main character. It is far from perfect, but I enjoyed it, that much I know. I think if you like games in this style, then you will probably enjoy it too; but if youâre someone who easily dislikes things that arenât absolutely perfectly crafted, you may want to reconsider trying this.

This game is not like other X:COM games you may have played; rather it is a different type of game altogether that is simply set in the X:COM universe. Evidently, this bothered many people; but I find it hard to understand why some people feel the core gameplay is so absolutely terrible. The style of play is very similar to the Mass Effect series. You combat in third-person shooter style, with the ability to use tactical pausing and to issue commands (move, target, use ability) to squadmates. There is an XP and leveling system for both your main character and squadmates, with a handful of different squadmate classes to work with. It certainly doesnât have the most refined, expansive, and exemplary combat/gameplay mechanics out there, but I thought it was good enough and enjoyed playing the game.

The story is somewhere between mediocre and good. I liked the atmosphere and setting of an alien invasion in 1960s America. The narrative and characters are undoubtedly clichÃ© at times, but I felt it was all intriguing enough to hold my interest as I played through the game. Some of the plot developments do come out of nowhere, but ultimately I thought they actually helped to make the story more interesting.

I didnât experience any jarring bugs or glitches and I thought the graphics and soundscape were pleasant. Some of the cutscenes had a grainy look to them even after I turned film grain off, but it wasnât the end of the worldâ the in-game graphics were still crisp and attractive. For me, the most egregious negative aspect of the game was the checkpoint autosave system. I donât like playing a game on a PC in this day & age and not have the option to quicksave and/or make multiple saves. (You can, however, also load up the start of any level and continue playing from there, if you missed something). But, to be honest, the checkpoints were extremely frequent and never really caused any true frustration.

The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a decent game that suffered from overzealous peopleâs unrealistic expectations. Not every game can be the best game ever or the best game of the year. If you are someone who only likes to play a few games a year and wants them all to be absolute top-notch games, I can respect that and I will then suggest that you might not want to play this. The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a moderate-to-good game that will appeal to those who enjoy the style of gameplay it offers and who play enough different games that they understand they canât all be the best but they can be good enough .

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

Posted: May 10
XCOM Declassified is a third-person shooter pleasant and able to give great satisfaction to skilled player thanks to the mechanics of managing agents who, in terms of gameplay experience, is able to distinguish the game from the competition and not enough to weigh a certain repetitive background. However, there are some flaws, starting with AI companions sometimes failed to arrive at a technical department not particularly optimized despite the look and feel of the game is not the highest level. But the fundamental point that does not allow the title to achieve a higher rating concerns the general sense of "approximation" that seems to affect the whole production. XCOM Declassified not have that little extra that can make it an inevitable game is enjoyable and fun to play but never fails to impress or to excel

Baphomet
294 products in account
111 reviews
Not Recommended
17.7 hrs on record
Posted: August 7
As far as games go, I can't think of too many that are more demonized than this one. Most people went into it thinking they were going to get some sort of polished up grid-style xcom team FPS and the reality is that while this game doesn't quite fall into that category, it isn't exactly the worst thing ever either.

The game itself has a fairly interesting storyline that fits in âokâ to the XCOM universe despite not making a whole lot of sense until late game. Most levels consist of you running from point A to point B and collecting whatever tidbits of information (if any) and special items/weapons in addition to killing anything in your way.

The combat is a bit frustrating at first as your cohorts movement commands are issued in a way relative to their position which makes using their abilities a bit difficult if they happen to be out of range. Also, they seem to be incredibly bad at dodging anything so expect to have to babysit them for the entirety of the game. As far as strategy goes, I managed to find a sweet spot with scout and commando but other class mixes are viable all the way until the last few battles (your experience may vary).

Overall, the game came off as a bit tedious and I kind of sloughed through the last few hours of "level plus multiple respawns". Additionally the plot revolving around the main character (Carter) is pretty nonsensical and random which made it kind of difficult to get âintoâ the story. I would only recommend this game for diehard fans of XCOM who want to see another take on the popular franchise.

Posted: June 11
I don't know why all the hate for this game. Played and enjoyed every minute of it.
Long story short: Aliens attack Earth you need to stop them.
Good parts:
Nice graphics and detailed levels.
The tactical combat is smooth and works well.
Badass main character Clint Eastwood type.
Captivating story with some cool twists.
Good voice-acting.

Bad parts-
Your team-mates are like potatos when you don't give them commands.
Overall bad AI.

If you like sci-fi, aliens stuff buy it on a sale it's great.

Was this review helpful? Yes No Funny
12 of 15 people (80%) found this review helpful
1 person found this review funny
Aurumlamina
902 products in account
61 reviews
Recommended
22.3 hrs on record
Posted: June 14
As a long time XCOM fan, I was uncertain about the direction of The Bureau. Here was a series that I loved with strong tactical strategy roots that had influenced the genre for nearly two decades... and it's newest release was going to be a third-person shooter. I assumed that the game was a way to use the XCOM name to cash in on yet another Call of Duty clone. Fast forward a couple of years and I realized that I was wrong.

The XCOM 2 announcement got me hyped up on the series once again and I decided that instead of playing through another war in XCOM: Enemy Within (which would've been a blast, even if it were my billionth war) I would try something new and actually give The Bureau a go. It was a good decision.

The story in the game is enjoyable, though it gets a little weird and unexpectedly complicated toward the end. Base building doesn't make an appearance in this game, however, there is an XCOM base where you spend your time in between missions and it is quite well done. Different scenes play out as you wander through the base depending on events that you've experienced and choices that you've made. For example, after defeating each new enemy type that you run across you can often see them being studied (in one way ot another) in your laboratory.

Combat, the meat and potatoes of this game, is significantly more fun than I had been assuming. You issue commands to your squad mates (who come in Recon, Engineer, Support, and Soldier varieties) which include utilizing the abilities that they possess. These squaddies level up and gain new abilities on a skill tree exclusive to each class that is reminiscent of XCOM: Enemy Unknown. Two agents of the same class could use their abilities in different ways.

The feel of the combat itself reminds me of Mass Effect 2. The cover system, the use of alien abilities (some which are very similar to biotics), and even the large variety of weapons to choose from in the game and their varying strengths and weaknesses. However, it can not be overstated that the AI in this game is less than amazing. You'll find yourself micromanaging your agents often as they can't seem to utilize themselves to be anywhere near as efficient as when you hold them by the hand and tell them what to do. On a few occassions, I watched in horror as one of my agents moved away from an enemy grenade, only to realize that the best cover was were that grenade was and return to it to his imminent death.

All in all, this is a good game with plenty to offer that I recommend to XCOM fans and shooter/RPG fans alike. As long as you can get past the AI it is a solid game with around a couple of dozen hours of content if you're playing on a difficulty level that challenges you.
